item.title:
Avoid the trap of local simplistic economics. You're submitting to journals but not reviewing so you're bad. Wrong. Look at the problem at a system level. How do we reduce the review burden for everyone?
The answer that seems to never to occur to whinging editors is simple.
item.description:
Avoid the trap of local simplistic economics. You're submitting to journals but not reviewing so you're bad. Wrong. Look at the problem at a system level. How do we reduce the review burden for everyone?
The answer that seems to never to occur to whinging editors is simple.
item.content:encoded: Avoid the trap of local simplistic economics. You're submitting to journals but not reviewing so you're bad. Wrong. Look at the problem at a system level. How do we reduce the review burden for everyone? The answer that seems to never to occur to whinging editors is simple.

item.title:
Abolish journals. They fuck us in two ways:
1) they are mostly owned by commercial publishers who will NEVER pay reviewers, and you will never get them to, no matter how much you complain, b/c academics for SOME reason decided to give them the power to manage peer review.
item.description:
Abolish journals. They fuck us in two ways:
1) they are mostly owned by commercial publishers who will NEVER pay reviewers, and you will never get them to, no matter how much you complain, b/c academics for SOME reason decided to give them the power to manage peer review.
item.content:encoded: Abolish journals. They fuck us in two ways: 1) they are mostly owned by commercial publishers who will NEVER pay reviewers, and you will never get them to, no matter how much you complain, b/c academics for SOME reason decided to give them the power to manage peer review.

item.title: 2) It's dreadfully inefficient. Submit to a journal. 20 reviewers invited. 3 accept. 2 give extensive comments, 1 professor gives a one-liner. Editor rejects. Subject to the next journal. 20 reviewers invited. 2 accept. 2 give detailed reviews. Editors rejects. Etc etc.
item.description: 2) It's dreadfully inefficient. Submit to a journal. 20 reviewers invited. 3 accept. 2 give extensive comments, 1 professor gives a one-liner. Editor rejects. Subject to the next journal. 20 reviewers invited. 2 accept. 2 give detailed reviews. Editors rejects. Etc etc.
item.content:encoded: 2) It's dreadfully inefficient. Submit to a journal. 20 reviewers invited. 3 accept. 2 give extensive comments, 1 professor gives a one-liner. Editor rejects. Subject to the next journal. 20 reviewers invited. 2 accept. 2 give detailed reviews. Editors rejects. Etc etc.

item.title:
This is fixable by centralising peer review rather than ceding all that power to journals and publishers
Use @PeerCommunityIn as a single hub for reviewing preprints, then let journals bid on the outcomes. https://t.co/ptFiWbQNnF
If we mobilised we could solve this very quickly

item.title: @KordingLab @Plinz @opherdonchin @jjodx It's also worth noting that decades of evidence have supported a role for synaptic changes in learning and memory. Though there some people like to pretend this question is up for grabs, it really isn't: we really do know that learning rests, in part, on synaptic changes.
item.description: @KordingLab @Plinz @opherdonchin @jjodx It's also worth noting that decades of evidence have supported a role for synaptic changes in learning and memory. Though there some people like to pretend this question is up for grabs, it really isn't: we really do know that learning rests, in part, on synaptic changes.
item.content:encoded: @KordingLab @Plinz @opherdonchin @jjodx It's also worth noting that decades of evidence have supported a role for synaptic changes in learning and memory. Though there some people like to pretend this question is up for grabs, it really isn't: we really do know that learning rests, in part, on synaptic changes.

item.title: @KordingLab @jjodx @Plinz @opherdonchin @sjo09 That's not for sure. Even with big changes, if there was some way that the system was engaged in a second-order estimate (telling it the curvature was low), it could very well be following the gradient appropriately with a big step.
item.description: @KordingLab @jjodx @Plinz @opherdonchin @sjo09 That's not for sure. Even with big changes, if there was some way that the system was engaged in a second-order estimate (telling it the curvature was low), it could very well be following the gradient appropriately with a big step.

Even with big changes, if there was some way that the system was engaged in a second-order estimate (telling it the curvature was low), it could very well be following the gradient appropriately with a big step.

item.title: @KordingLab @Plinz @opherdonchin @jjodx Another possible source of learning is "in-context" learning via activity dynamics, which I suspect underlies most learning during the day. But, the kind of learning that needs consolidation during sleep surely does involve many small synaptic changes.
item.description: @KordingLab @Plinz @opherdonchin @jjodx Another possible source of learning is "in-context" learning via activity dynamics, which I suspect underlies most learning during the day. But, the kind of learning that needs consolidation during sleep surely does involve many small synaptic changes.

But, the kind of learning that needs consolidation during sleep surely does involve many small synaptic changes.

item.title: @elonmusk Also, there way more insects than humans by weight, and by number of neurons: - 1E19 insects at 1E5 neurons per insect = 1E24 insect neurons. - 1E10 humans at 1E11 neurons per human = 1E21 human neurons. Insects "outsmart" us by a factor of 1000. But I'm not particularly worried.

item.title:
Worrying about superhuman AI alignment today is like worrying turbojet engine safety in 1920.
We do not have a working design for anything that could come close to becoming as smart as a dog, let alone a domestic robot that can clear the dinner table & fill up the dishwasher.

item.title: And the idea that intelligent systems will inevitably want to take over, dominate humans, or just destroy humanity through negligence is preposterous. They would have to be specifically designed to do so. Whereas we will obviously design them to not do so.

item.title:
Making AI safe is going to happen as with every new technology (e.g. cars, airplanes, etc): it's going to be a process of iterative refinement.
And again, getting that slightly wrong may hurt some people (as cars and airplanes have) but will not wipe out humanity.

item.title: I'm not saying it's going to be easy, just like making jetliners as reliable as they are today hasn't been easy. But making it sound like it's an unsolvable problem is, at the very least, extremely premature, and most likely just false.

item.title:
But regardless, until we have a semi credible design, we are discussing the sex of angels.
The worst that can happen is that we won't figure out a good way to make them safe and we won't deploy them.
Sort of like nuclear-powered cars and rockets that were promised in the 1950s

item.title:
One of the crucial roles a meerkat plays is the watch guard. One meerkat will stand on its hind legs and act as a lookout, scanning for predators. Sometimes, the vantage point they choose can be very peculiar
[source, Nick Kleer: https://t.co/kw72VCu5Tf] https://t.co/gANC9RrHcJ
